text: @LTKthescientist Love this so much for you 🎉
@AnwenBill You're welcome. I share my experience to hopefully raise awareness about the issues with ADHD diagnosis and treatment. I hope you and your family can get support soon!

Wild day in academia for me: 
started out by finding a paper with 0 acknowledgement of my contributions for a project I worked on in its early stages & ended with the most inclusive meeting I’ve ever had - we spent 1/3 of meeting ensuring everyone’s accessibility needs were met. https://t.co/iajv7f2wql

RT @SofiaAtSea: Last week marked the end for Season 2 of the Good Natured @ConservOptimism podcast 🎧 - https://t.co/mZmBwEpGyc

Here are so…

19. ADHD medication is lifesaving! I know people with ADHD (and depression/anxiety) on meds whose mental health issues have greatly improved and are thriving. It breaks my heart to know of thousands of people struggling and waiting years on the NHS unable to access care. https://t.co/44favNwPyy

18. The first time I took the ADHD meds it was an emotional experience. I cried. It was the first time in my life that my head was calm, quiet, with no internal monologue. Things that took me a day to finish I did in a few hours. It has been life changing perhaps saving too. https://t.co/Ova90GxZed

17. I have to stay 3 months stable on ADHD meds before I can transfer to NHS care. I can’t wait, as I’ve already spent > £2000 accessing a private diagnosis and treatment, which on a PhD stipend + part time job, living in one of the most expensive UK cities is hard. https://t.co/8M1bZt31rl

16. To exchange ADHD meds prescription it takes a 2-hour roundtrip (bus + walk). The clinic is ironically not ADHD/autism friendly with a radio blasting, coffee machine loudly gurgling & walls covered in colourful posters flapping in the breeze. It’s a sensory nightmare. https://t.co/lfdImqYl5X

15. The prescription for my ADHD meds arrive the next day! I notice it says the higher dose but as 1 pill rather than 3 pills, which was agreed by nurse. I email the clinic to ask for new prescription. They say I can only get a new one if I return old one in person. https://t.co/bd2NKXvgAM

14. I had my first ADHD nurse consultation (online) the other day costing £200 & it honestly could have been an email. It lasted 16 minutes. All my values were good, and the nurse and I agreed for me to go up a dose from 2 pills to 3. I asked for prescription to be posted to me. https://t.co/QWKNUNEvI8

13. To book the £200 obligatory monthly 30-min consultation at my private ADHD clinic I can only do this by phoning in, as there is no option to email (I asked). I am autistic so phone calls are anxiety inducing. Did I mention this clinic also does autism diagnoses? https://t.co/YiKDx8sGWI

12. To access ADHD meds ASAP after diagnosis I had to stay on privately. I now pay £200 a month for a 30-min nurse consultation & pay for meds which for a month is about £100. They said I should phone various pharmacies to get cheapest deal on meds!? https://t.co/uVWDYutgdE

11. We then discussed ADHD meds. I was told I could take my private ADHD diagnosis to my NHS Dr & request meds BUT I would have to wait a minimum 2 yrs to access meds, as I would 1st need referral to a psychiatric specialist & join wait list with people seeking a diagnosis! https://t.co/VooSE25vKF

10. At the end of the 2nd assessment the assessor confirmed what I already knew that I do in fact have ADHD but that it was “mild”. I was too exhausted to push back on the ableist remark after sharing my MH & ADHD struggles for >1 hour. https://t.co/CXZyqMd6i7

9. TW suicide, self-harm. 

In January I had my 2 ADHD assessments. 1st one focused discussing questionnaire about struggles as a child & adult. 2nd one was triggering as they ask Qs about your MH (e.g. suicide, self-harm) to rule out other diagnoses like bipolar or BPD. https://t.co/laRs0Ouc3u

8. Along with filling in 2 long forms to join the wait list for the ADHD assessments I needed to send them 6 forms which were a mix of questionnaires filled in by myself, a parent and partner. Navigating these complex forms was a challenge for my executive function! https://t.co/yHJsdfH6e2

7. To afford a private ADHD diagnosis, I took on a part time job, saved money from talks I gave, cut back on spending to save about >1 month’s PhD stipend. I made sure I had at least 1/2 amount before joining waiting list, so by the time my assessment came I had the full amount. https://t.co/Mzw0kIdbvG

6. I looked into NHS route (Right to Chose) but the waiting list was so long, but shorter than going through GP first. Private had a wait time of 5 months but cost >1 month of my PhD stipend. I weighed my options and decided for my MH and PhD my only option was to go private. https://t.co/l0My3fLOGV

5. I went to my disability advisory service with my concerns and was told they were unable to refer me for an ADHD diagnosis, like my autism diagnosis referral. They suggested I go via the NHS (several years on the waiting list) or private route (a few months waiting list). https://t.co/LXjipuDysU

4. Also want to give a shout out to the awesome @ADHDHive which I discovered early on in my ADHD discovery journey! Honestly being in a judgement-free and supportive space with peeps with your neurotype is wonderful. https://t.co/hk252uOWus

3. After trying out various paid apps, negative self-talk, courses to help manage my ADHD. Nothing really helped me feel better or be more productive and I was close to quitting my PhD program. Self-diagnosis was not enough for me in order to access medical treatment. https://t.co/cHuTZKfDri

2. I did the autistic/ADHD thing of doing a deep dive (hyper focus) into journal articles about ADHD, watching YouTube videos, talking to other ADHD people. This was an affirming journey and I started feeling comfortable to self-diagnose. https://t.co/o3sm9No7XL

1. I’ve known since 2020 that I have ADHD. There were things that I was experiencing that my autism and dyslexia diagnoses couldn’t fully explain like: high distractibility, near-constant fidgeting, very poor executive functioning and emotional regulation issues. https://t.co/AjhlHxwkh2

A 🧵 on navigating a formal #ADHD diagnosis in the UK as a PhD student.

Tl;dr: ADHD self-diagnosis is valid, but formal diagnosis needed to access meds. Go private if you can afford it, assessment process is opaque, emotionally draining & ableist. ADHD meds are life-saving. 👇
Appreciating all the little joys I can during these hard times 💜 https://t.co/G41EuX7O1T

For non-autistic/ADHD peeps, stimming is short for self-stimulating behaviour which is repetitive. Pretty much everyone stims, but autistic/ADHD peeps do this more frequently/intensely to self-sooth or for fun. Common stims: rocking, hair twirling, leg bouncing, hand flapping.

Today I gave a short talk to a group of Oxford University staff about #EDI (mostly on disability) and I realised it was the first time I was fully unmasked and super stimmy when giving a talk. It was liberating to show up as my authentic self. #ActuallyAutistic https://t.co/L5mgvKg56g

8. Where we are in conservation and where we want to be, beautifully illustrated by Barkha Lohia. By recognising, addressing past & current harms/barriers, we can start creating an equitable, just & inclusive space where BIPOC can thrive in conservation science & practice. https://t.co/6tNBw0E659

7.Creating inclusive, safe & welcoming space for BIPOC is essential in conservation science & practice. We outline 7 ways to do this e.g. ensuring ‘essential’ work experience is built into degree programmes & learning cultural history & norms of communities whose land you work on https://t.co/XuthpBT7ut

6. We also share 9 ways to better conduct research and practice conservation from building more interdisciplinary collaborations to ensuring fair dissemination of funds to BIPOC academics/practitioners/organisations. https://t.co/8GdhpFFOFb
5. We present 8 suggestions to recognise and address the unjust history of conservation science that cover personal actions to professional associations. https://t.co/NVIU3Pg5fP

4.Before we can find solutions to the systemic racism in conservation science & practice we need to identify & address the historical & contemporary barriers & harms faced overwhelmingly by Black Indigenous & People of Colour (BIPOC) e.g. fortress conservation & parachute science https://t.co/Xv5AtCGW1C

3. Our activities in conservation sci & practice spheres shape what happens in each sphere. Colonial & racist history in conservation practice influences how academia frames conservation issues, solutions, curricula & type of interactions with students,peers & local people’s land https://t.co/5cwfrSHC7U

2. First off, we define the twin spheres as conservation science: teaching & research, typically taking place at academic institutions e.g. university campuses & conservation practice as applied conservation policies & programmes, which occurs away from campuses. https://t.co/EvoMJqdbbO
1. We are an interdisciplinary group of authors at varying career stages from 11 countries across 6 continents! https://t.co/r4PRnIqiXM

RT @sara_lil_plants: Sadly academic ableism is rife. For non-disabled academics/managers here are 20+ questions to sit with and take action…

When you think about what a disabled person looks like, what comes to mind? Have you challenged your own biases and assumptions you have towards disabled/neurodivergent people? Have you read articles/books by disabled people? Have you looked at #WhyDisabledPeopleDropOut? 8/8

When giving presentations or lectures, do you provide different options for people to engage (e.g. anonymous polls, hands up, white board and pens)? Are your presentations with visual aids accessible in terms of colour and font type? Do you put AltText in your Twitter images? 7/8

Are lab spaces accessible to disabled people who use mobility aids? Are lecture theatres accessible, and not just for disabled audience members but also for potential speakers? Are departmental social events inclusive? 6/8

Do you have a quiet room in your department building which can be used by neurodivergent people to decompress? Can the lighting in offices be adjusted? Are closed captions available in online talks? Doing an in-person event? Have you provided options to participate remotely? 5/8

When implementing a new policy have you co-designed this, or have you sought feedback after the fact? How are you defining success? Is your definition of success inclusive to disabled/neurodivergent peeps? Has a student disclosed their disability to you? What did you do next? 4/8

Have you commissioned focus groups with disabled/neurodivergent students and actively listened to feedback on how to improve things? Do you know how many students have left their courses due to academic ableism? 3/8

Senior management: Are you aware if your harassment policies and procedures are inclusive of neurodiversity/disability? Is training given to PIs/lecturers in how to best support neurodivergent students? Have you been trained how to support your neurodivergent faculty members? 2/8

I encourage neurotypical academics to actively and regularly engage with neurodivergent students and academics about their experiences in order to build a more inclusive and just academic workspace where neurodivergent people don’t just survive but thrive! /13

I don’t believe the authors of this article intended to be ableist. But this speaks to the wider issue of why we need diverse teams with a variety of lived experiences in academia so we can build more inclusive structures and narratives /12

For a further break down of the other tips covered in this article from a neurodivergent perspective see the excellent thread by @geology_johnson 

https://t.co/RGPqM41gdT  /11

Many autistic people also have alexithymia which is the inability to understand and describe our or other people’s emotions. This does not mean we can’t feel emotions, but it does mean it takes us time to interpret what another person is saying and respond appropriately /10

Many autistic people find eye contact physically painful and anxiety inducing. Just because we are not making eye does not mean we aren’t engaged or actively listening. We may engage and respond to conversations in different ways e.g. stimming, silence or loud exclamations /9

The authors share 5 tips about how to improve emotional intelligence in academic workplaces through: 1) Identifying our emotions, 2) considering our responses, 3) empathy, 4) active listening and 5) mastering our body language. I want to draw attention to #5 /8 https://t.co/XEEj1ABCMS

These neurotypical societal structures and expectations also carry through into academia. Academic policies, initiatives and discussions (such as this Nature Careers article on emotional intelligence) need to be mindful of unconscious bias and the perpetuation of ableism /7

Things like sitting down for many hours at school or work, teamwork, being in large open plan offices, noisy and bright shopping centres can be difficult for neurodivergent people due to sensory sensitivities and communication challenges /6

Neurodivergent people experience and interact with the world differently to neurotypicals and often find it challenging to navigate a society from education system to workplaces that is built by and for neurotypicals /5

Both neurodivergent and neurotypical brains form part of the natural variation of human neurology encompassed by neurodiversity. The term neurodiversity was coined by Judy Singer, a sociologist in the 90's /4

Neurodivergent (ND) is an umbrella term used to describe a person whose brain functioning & processing significantly diverges from the neurotypical societal majority. Some ND examples: autism, ADHD, tourettes, OCD, dyslexia, dyspraxia, dyscalculia & dysgraphia /3
These are my thoughts as someone who is a PhD student and neurodivergent (autistic, ADHD and dyslexic). Disclaimer I don't speak for all neurodivergent people /2.
Whilst I welcome this discussion on the importance of emotional intelligence in academia, this article is not inclusive to neurodivergent people. A thread /1 https://t.co/XNZebUlakI

We are mourning the loss of what our projects could have been & UKRI’s decision is a slap in the face to thousands of hardworking PhD students. I urge UKRI to reconsider this decision urgently /8

Whilst I understand difficult decisions have to be made, this one is ill thought out, going against UKRI’s vision & mission, cruel & detrimental in the long-term to us personally but also to society. Plus the UK is going to need all the trained people it can get with #brexit /7

This decision will disproportionately affect underrepresented groups e.g. #BAME #disabled #chronicallyill #neurodiverse students, which will lead to an even leakier pipeline, with even less representation of these groups in/outside of academia /6

We're worried about the financial impacts. Whilst we are lucky to have funding, we have small stipends where >50% goes on rent & bills, some of us teach or have part-time jobs to support ourselves. We are facing a prospect of finishing off our PhDs without funding/dropping out /5
A PhD is a process of learning, collaborating & refining our skills that we can use for careers within & outside academia. This decision affects all these aspects & the quality of our outputs /4

My PhD colleagues & I are now facing hard short-term & long-term decisions: How to restructure our field/lab projects with little to no data, whether to do a training course or internship, whether or not to sit on #EDI committees, take part in extracurricular activities /3

We’ve all been impacted by #COVID. Many of us have worsened mental health, are lonely, missing our family & friends, working from home in spaces not fit to work in, some of us have had to care for relatives, shielding or suffering the effects of #longcovid /2

I have been thinking more about UKRI’s decision not to fund extensions to PhD students despite the global #COVID pandemic. We are people not numbers on a spreadsheet. We work hard to create impactful research which addresses some of society’s big challenges. A thread /1

I’m launching a project @BlackBritishBio where I’m uncovering historical contributions of Black Britons in the biological sciences. There must be many contributions from Black naturalists that we don’t know about yet. I wonder how many more John Edmonstone’s there are out there? https://t.co/sJPEFSvRpE

Part of decolonising science is also about including a diverse set of scientific voices both past and present. This is especially critical today given the great challenges we face (e.g. #climatechange #biodiversityloss #soildegradation #plasticpollution)

We need to look critically at the “great” historic scientists & share the good the bad & the ugly side of their work. It’s not about banishing them from the textbooks, but rather acknowledging the socio-political implications of their work, because science is always political.

We’re tired of constantly grieving because another black person has been murdered by police 9/9

~Sara Middleton
#BlackLivesMatter  #GeorgeFloyd #JusticeForGeorgeFloyd #racism

We’re tired of carrying the store receipt in our hand as we leave the store, so as not to cause suspicion of stealing

We’re tired of talking about race 

We’re tired of being asked to come up with solutions to fix diversity issues at work  8/9

We’re tired of people calling the police on us when we are trying to enjoy nature

We’re tired of people sleeping with us just because “it would be fun to try something exotic” 7/9

We’re tired of being unfairly overlooked for promotion at work

We’re tired of people in position of power not calling out racism 

We’re tired of seeing people clutching their bags as we walk past on the street 6/9

We’re tired that we are overrepresented in the prison systems and underrepresented in our higher education institutions

We’re tired that “nude fashion clothing” means only shades of white

We’re tired of being refused entrance to a bar or restaurant for no good reason 5/9

We’re tired of people saying our hair is ugly, untidy or unprofessional

We’re tired of the healthcare racial disparities

We’re tired that you dig our music but don’t want to engage in our struggles 4/9

We’re tired of being followed by security staff around in stores when we do our shopping

We’re tired of explaining to people who say “I don’t see colour”

We’re tired of explaining to people who say “well I am not racist”

We’re tired of being called “monkey” or “ape” 3/9

We’re tired

We’re tired of looking over our shoulder every time we leave the house

We’re tired of working twice as hard to get anywhere

We’re tired of watching our tone so as not to come across as aggressive 2/9
